<p><strong>As COVID-19 cases</strong> oscillate in the United States, the impact of the pandemic continues to affect many workers. The COVID-19 crisis and the related levels of burnout that people are experiencing at work remain <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/great-attrition-or-great-attraction-the-choice-is-yours">pervasive problems</a>, especially among employed parents, according to a new McKinsey survey.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="908bc1bd-a48d-4d97-88f2-ad822a800452"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="908bc1bd-a48d-4d97-88f2-ad822a800452" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on McKinsey survey data of employees in the United States. The survey was open for responses between July 7 and July 14, 2021; n = 3,007. Of those surveyed, 862 were employed parents. We use the term employed parents to refer to individuals who work outside the home and who are parents/caregivers of children aged 18 and younger who live at home.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This article was a collaborative effort by <a href="/our-people/erica-coe">Erica Coe</a>, <a href="/our-people/kana-enomoto">Kana Enomoto</a>, Brad Herbig, <a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7bcba1055e-f3c5-41e6-a48b-7a250018c5ba%7d%40en">Ashish Kothari</a>, and Jeris Stueland, representing views from across the Healthcare Systems and Services Practice.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Burnout arises when individuals cannot access enough recovery between stressors.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="351302b3-6e05-4827-8b2f-60c4a2fa3bca"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="351302b3-6e05-4827-8b2f-60c4a2fa3bca" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Burnout is defined by the World Health Organization, in its 11th revision of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11), as a syndrome resulting from chronic workplace stress that has not been successfully managed. Burnout is characterized by three dimensions: (1) feelings of energy depletion or exhaustion, (2) increased mental distance from ones job or feelings of negativism or cynicism related to ones job, and (3) reduced professional efficacy.</span></span></span></a></span> Employed parents face higher numbers of and longer exposure to stressors from the multiple roles they play, compared with nonparents, and they have less ability to access periods of recovery as a result.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="91445470-219b-47e0-b812-70cc9386b806"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="91445470-219b-47e0-b812-70cc9386b806" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">When managed well, experiencing stress can serve a purposeit can help us to solve problems and to learn and grow. However, when left unmanaged, stress can lead to burnout. For more, see Jan Ascher and Fleur Tonies, <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/how-to-turn-everyday-stress-into-optimal-stress">How to turn everyday stress into optimal stress</a>, <em>McKinsey Quarterly</em>, February 18, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Employed parents report several stressors in particular: a lack of worklife balance, increased responsibilities at both work and home, greater concern for safety at work around COVID-19 infection, a loss of social support and increased isolation, and recent organizational changes affecting their jobs. While the pandemic has had an impact on all employees, this article focuses on the experiences of employed parents in particular.</p>
<p>Compared with nonparents, employed parents are twice as likely to strongly agree that they:</p>
<ul>
    <li>are worn out at the end of the day,</li>
    <li>used to find their work more interesting, and</li>
    <li>sometimes think their work is insignificant.</li>
</ul>
<p>In addition to the pandemic-related challenges that people around the world are facingincluding illness, financial worry, and isolation from friends and familyemployed parents in the United States have had distinct challenges stemming from the COVID-19 crisis. As our survey of employed parents indicates, the compound pressure of working while parenting, including remote schooling and working, has left many citing feelings of apathy and fatigue, and as if they are failing to live up to their own expectations across their multiple social roles. These may include expectations related to not only being a parent, but as a spouse, friend, family member, or caregiver.</p>
<p>There are also indications that parents are not finding the help they need from their employers. For example, in our survey, parents reporting symptoms of burnout are 90 percent more likely to report that they believe senior management at their workplace considers productivity to be more important than mental health.</p>
<p>Populations of color have faced disproportionate job losses and are experiencing a death toll twice that of the White population from COVID-19.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fdd7e208-4bf3-40e1-ae87-67118ca01900"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fdd7e208-4bf3-40e1-ae87-67118ca01900" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For example, Black Americans; for more, see Aria Florant, Nick Noel, Shelley Stewart, and Jason Wright, <a href="/industries/social-sector/our-insights/covid-19-investing-in-black-lives-and-livelihoods">COVID-19: Investing in Black lives and livelihoods</a>, McKinsey, April 14, 2020. See also The color of coronavirus: COVID-19 deaths by race and ethnicity in the U.S., APM Research Lab, March 5, 2021; and Ella Koeze, A year later, who is back to work and who is not?, <em>New York Times</em>, March 9, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Less than a third of employed parents of color said, I enjoy my work. I have no symptoms of burnout, compared with almost half of White parents who said the same.</p>
<p>Beyond facing more health-specific concerns and health-related trauma in their communities, employed parents of color have also had more challenges around childcare. For example, families of color have been more likely than White families to experience pandemic-related childcare closures.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="13196526-48eb-47b3-ae4c-242b6cd47013"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="13196526-48eb-47b3-ae4c-242b6cd47013" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Claire Cain Miller, Return to work? Not with child care still in limbo, some parents say, <em>New York Times</em>, updated October 9, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>While our survey analysis focused on US respondents, parents around the globe are experiencing fatigue and stress.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="19e82b43-ddf1-4e01-a9fe-fbd745e16d37"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="19e82b43-ddf1-4e01-a9fe-fbd745e16d37" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Selected quotes from Dynata Survey conducted between September 15 and September 30, 2021. Survey sample size was 1,258; n = 421 employed parents who reported experiencing burnout. Countries surveyed included Australia (n = 50), Canada (n = 50), China (n = 59), Germany (n = 55), India (n = 50), Singapore (n = 50), the United Kingdom (n = 57), and the United States (n = 50).</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/healthcare/how-we-help-clients">Healthcare Systems & Services Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Visit our Center for Societal Benefit through Healthcare page</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-md-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>The stresses and pressures of being a parent mixed with the demands of work have made life nearly impossible.</p><cite class="mdc-c-blockquote__cite-container"><div class="mdc-c-blockquote__author-name___u4L7-_990311c">Caregiver of two children, United Kingdom</div></cite></blockquote></div>
<p>Many employers are recognizing these challenges and are beginning to develop and implement strategies to support their employees in new and different ways. The research and perspectives presented here are offered to support employers as they define and refine their approaches. In the charts below, we highlight some of the meaningful findings from the research and identify actions that employers could consider.</p>
<h2>Causes of burnout for employed parents stem from both the home and the workplace</h2>
<!-- -->
<p>Of the six main causes of burnoutan unsustainable workload, a general perceived lack of control, insufficient rewards for effort, the lack of a supportive community, absence of fairness, and mismatched values and skillsmany are challenges that employed parents may be more likely to face, particularly in a pandemic.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="924c7fd8-14b5-4461-904f-d29e3ed28acd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="924c7fd8-14b5-4461-904f-d29e3ed28acd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Susan E. Jackson et al., Making a significant difference with burnout interventions: Researcher and practitioner collaboration, <em>Journal of Organizational Behavior</em>, February 2012, Volume 33, Number 2, pp. 296300.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-md-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Its a lot. Having no break from kids or working at night. No time to switch off.</p><cite class="mdc-c-blockquote__cite-container"><div class="mdc-c-blockquote__author-name___u4L7-_990311c">Caregiver of two children, Australia</div></cite></blockquote></div>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-left-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>73% of parents with symptoms of burnout report that the demands of their work interfere with their private and family life, compared to 38% of parents without</p></blockquote></div>
<p>Employed parents report a range of stressors that have deteriorated their mental health. The level of household responsibilities is a particular problem. In our survey, parents experiencing symptoms of burnout are more often responsible for all household duties, compared with parents not experiencing symptoms of burnout (57 percent versus 41 percent).</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-right-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>69% of parents with symptoms of burnout report that recent organizational changes have significantly affected their job, compared to 49% of parents without</p></blockquote></div>
<p>In fact, the majority of parents responsible for all household duties report symptoms of burnout. These responsibilities, for example, including caring for <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/supporting-unpaid-caregivers-in-crisis-a-talk-with-alexandra-drane"> older adult family members</a> in addition to children, most often fall to women, who have also been more likely to cut back on paid work during the COVID-19 pandemic in order to provide childcare.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fa3c76f4-5fba-48f2-a3ed-03728c387544"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fa3c76f4-5fba-48f2-a3ed-03728c387544" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See Megan Brenan, Women still handle main household tasks in U.S, Gallup, January 29, 2020; and Claire Cain Miller, The pandemic created a child-care crisis. Mothers bore the burden, <em>New York Times</em>, May 17, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> For these women specifically, reduced paid time at work could also serve to further exacerbate the symptoms of burnout they are experiencing, if their responsibilities at work do not also decrease.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-md-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Trying to balance work demands, running a household, paying bills, dealing with [the] issues of an elderly parent, as well as providing emotional support to my son has left me burnt out.</p><cite class="mdc-c-blockquote__cite-container"><div class="mdc-c-blockquote__author-name___u4L7-_990311c">Caregiver of one child, Australia</div></cite></blockquote></div>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-edge-to-edge StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__TLkZC mck-c-module-wrapper"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="white" data-module-category="" class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__item__YhXnX"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>Rates of mental-health challenges among children have increased during the pandemic, acting as a critical stressor for employed parents</div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p>Parents are not the only ones facing mental-health challenges. Throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, the lack of in-person education, reduced social interaction, and widespread uncertainty have <a href="/industries/education/our-insights/covid-19-and-education-the-lingering-effects-of-unfinished-learning">taken a toll on children as well</a>. Even as many schools have returned to in-person classes, readapting to previously familiar academic and social circumstances is provoking anxiety and fear among some children and adolescents.</p>

<p>Parents seeking mental healthcare for their children are struggling to find help; for the approximately 15 million children in the United States, there are only 8,000 to 9,000 psychiatrists, and even fewer are in-network or financially accessible.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1cf437e6-8cab-40be-862a-05296b2a3a72"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1cf437e6-8cab-40be-862a-05296b2a3a72" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Alfred Lubrano, The pandemic is exacerbating a shortage of child therapists, <em>Philadelphia Inquirer</em>, February 2, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Parents are understandably worried. Four in five employed parents say that they feel concerned about their childs mental health, and more than one-third rate this concern as extreme.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e1f89f31-018f-4829-bf63-50c8a6881d86"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e1f89f31-018f-4829-bf63-50c8a6881d86" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on a McKinsey survey of 16,370 parents across all 50 US states. For more, see Emma Dorn, Bryan Hancock, Jimmy Sarakatsannis, and Ellen Viruleg, <a href="/industries/education/our-insights/covid-19-and-education-the-lingering-effects-of-unfinished-learning">COVID-19 and education: The lingering effects of unfinished learning</a>, McKinsey, July 27, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/covid%2019%20and%20burnout%20are%20straining%20the%20mental%20health%20of%20employed%20parents/svg-burnout-exhibit-1-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Concern about child's mental health" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/covid%2019%20and%20burnout%20are%20straining%20the%20mental%20health%20of%20employed%20parents/svg-burnout-exhibit-1-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-md-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>I cannot concentrate on my work and always worry about my childs health.</p><cite class="mdc-c-blockquote__cite-container"><div class="mdc-c-blockquote__author-name___u4L7-_990311c">Caregiver of one child, Canada</div></cite></blockquote></div>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-edge-to-edge StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__TLkZC mck-c-module-wrapper"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="white" data-module-category="" class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__item__YhXnX"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>Parents mental-health challenges correlate to their feelings about work</div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p>In our survey, parents are more likely than nonparents to report missing days of work because they are experiencing symptoms of burnout. They are also are more likely to use leaves of absence and supported employment.</p>

<p>While employed parents are more likely than nonparents to see themselves staying at their employer in two years time (79 percent versus 64 percent), burnout correlates to employed parents likelihood of not recommending their place of work to others. Their perspective on senior managements <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/overcoming-stigma-three-strategies-toward-better-mental-health-in-the-workplace">attitude toward the importance of mental health</a>, as well as the level of supportiveness their employer shows toward colleagues with mental illness, also declines.</p>

<p>Whats more, stress and burnout, both of which employed parents experience disproportionately more than nonparents, are the main reasons that cause people to consider leaving their jobs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" <div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-md-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>[My employer could better support me through allowing me] to work flexibly . . . [so that] when I need to take care of my family, I can work remotely . . . [and by] providing more health support, such as childcare services and mental-health consultations.</p><cite class="mdc-c-blockquote__cite-container"><div class="mdc-c-blockquote__author-name___u4L7-_990311c">Caregiver of two children, China</div></cite></blockquote></div>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="The well-being of working parents" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/covid%2019%20and%20burnout%20are%20straining%20the%20mental%20health%20of%20employed%20parents/standard-covid-working-parents-disruptor.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>The well-being of working parents</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="https://covid-tracker.mckinsey.com/working-parents" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c" target="_blank"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Explore the interactive</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-external-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h2>Employers can consider taking a preventative approach toward burnout</h2>
<p>Measures that support flexibility and resiliency can help ensure that all employees are engaged in their mental wellness.</p>
<p>Flexible working policies can be a critical tool for both parent and nonparent employees. Parents with access to flexible working policies are substantially less likely to show symptoms of burnout. Conversely, parents reporting symptoms of burnout who are unaware of flexible policies at work are more likely to request similar policies and to believe that these options would benefit them.</p>
<p>It is important for employers to realize that flexible working policies can come in many forms, going beyond remote-work options and including options such as reducing an individuals work responsibilities and offering part-time work.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-left-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Parents who reported being offered flexible working schedules were 31% more likely than parents without access to flexible working schedules to not be exhibiting any strong signs of burnout.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>The following are the top policies and benefits that parents were most likely to request to support their mental health:</p>
<ul>
    <li>flexible work schedule</li>
    <li>remote-work options (independent of the COVID-19 pandemic)</li>
    <li>family-support services (eg, childcare or dependent-care stipends, backup care)</li>
    <li>skill-building programs (eg, sleep improvement, stress-management programs)</li>
    <li>family or medical leave for mental-health conditions</li>
</ul>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-md-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>[Employers should] allow more flexibility in terms of working in the office and from home so that employees can better take care of both their work and family matters.</p><cite class="mdc-c-blockquote__cite-container"><div class="mdc-c-blockquote__author-name___u4L7-_990311c">Caregiver of three children, Singapore</div></cite></blockquote></div>
<h2>Employers can consider certain initiatives to better support employed parents experiencing burnout</h2>
<p>Employers <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/national-surveys-reveal-disconnect-between-employees-and-employers-around-mental-health-need">taking steps</a> to address their employees mental healthincluding helping them to feel included and valuedcan begin this journey by actively listening to their employees to better understand the challenges they face and <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/future-proof-solving-the-adaptability-paradox-for-the-long-term">by acting on what they hear</a>.</p>
<p>For employers, actively supporting parents mental health can lead to many forms of positive impact. By <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/overcoming-pandemic-fatigue-how-to-reenergize-organizations-for-the-long-run">taking steps to prevent burnout and stress</a>, an employer can help enable both employees and their families to thrive. Additionally, by acting to prevent and reduce burnout among employed parents, employers are not only supporting a population that, in turn, is more likely to remain in the workforce down the line and to endorse the organization to others, but also <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/women-in-the-workplace-archive">creating a more supportive organization overall</a>.</p>
<p>Subsequent steps may include the following.</p>
<h3>Make parents feel heard</h3>
<ul>
    <li>Managers can lead with compassion, working with their teams on promoting well-being, addressing stress, exhaustion, and burnout, and encouraging open discussion on topics of mental health by sharing their own stories.</li>
    <li>Involve parents in conversations around how they would most appreciate employer support, particularly in times of uncertainty (for example, on topics such as return to in-person working and organizational changes). Consider affinity groups to help foster connectivity.</li>
    <li>Refine organizational support plans for parents by addressing uncovered pain points and needs.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Build a work culture that supports mental health</h3>
<ul>
    <li>Establish flexibility around remote working (for example, flexibility to work from home as needed, or flexible hours) and communicate expectations early. Establish formal boundaries to help prevent employees from feeling that they need to be always on (for example, policies that make it clear that employees are not expected to respond to nonurgent requests outside of traditional working hours). Allow managers to work with direct reports in defining their responsibilities.</li>
    <li>Allow employees to adjust their workload as needed to tend to caregiving responsibilities, with ability to transition between full and part time as is feasible. When possible, allow employees to transition to more time-flexible roles (for example, from an inbound to an outbound call center, or from a direct customer-facing role to one involving document review).</li>
    <li>Structure performance reviews to reemphasize that employees are evaluated on results over simply where or what hours they work. Ensure in day-to-day and formal communications that leaders are not inadvertently signaling that long hours and face time are measures of performance.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Provide critical resources aligned with employees priorities</h3>
<ul>
    <li>Offer clear guidance on navigating the healthcare landscape for employed parents to support their or their childrens mental-health needs (for example, by creating a central internal landing page highlighting in-network child therapists).</li>
    <li>Consider providing more options for childcare support (for example, subsidized, on-site, or back-up childcare), nursing services, and other home- and family-focused benefits, showing value and support of employees as people juggling multiple roles.</li>
    <li>Ensure that benefits and other programs supporting mental health (for example, digital wellness apps) include access for close family members, such as employees children.</li>
</ul></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/erica-coe">Erica Coe</a></strong> is a partner in McKinseys Atlanta office, and <strong><a href="/our-people/kana-enomoto">Kana Enomoto</a></strong> is a senior knowledge expert in the Washington, DC, officethey are coleaders of the <a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b7a6990ca-f9c8-4e94-a5f0-6033ed632d1c%7d%40en">Center for Societal Benefit through Healthcare</a>; <strong>Brad Herbig</strong> is a consultant in the Philadelphia office; <strong><a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7bcba1055e-f3c5-41e6-a48b-7a250018c5ba%7d%40en">Ashish Kothari</a></strong> is a partner in the Denver office; and <strong>Jeris Stueland</strong> is an expert associate partner in the Minneapolis office.</p>
<p>The authors would like to thank Eric Bochtler, Jacqueline Brassey, Alistair Carmichael, Jenny Cordina, Alexandra King, Maria Mendoza, Bob van der Mortel, and Michelle Tang for their contributions to this article.</p>

and burnout are straining the mental health of employed parents"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"COVID-19 on mental health of employed parents"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Employed parents cite apathy and fatigue in new survey."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-12-17T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAs COVID-19 cases\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;oscillate in the United States, the impact of the pandemic continues to affect many workers. The COVID-19 crisis and the related levels of burnout that people are experiencing at work remain \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/great-attrition-or-great-attraction-the-choice-is-yours\"\u003epervasive problems\u003c/a\u003e, especially among employed parents, according to a new McKinsey survey.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar authors]]\n\u003cp\u003eBurnout arises when individuals cannot access enough recovery between stressors.[[footnote 2]] Employed parents face higher numbers of and longer exposure to stressors from the multiple roles they play, compared with nonparents, and they have less ability to access periods of recovery as a result.[[footnote 3]] Employed parents report several stressors in particular: a lack of work\u0026ndash;life balance, increased responsibilities at both work and home, greater concern for safety at work around COVID-19 infection, a loss of social support and increased isolation, and recent organizational changes affecting their jobs. While the pandemic has had an impact on all employees, this article focuses on the experiences of employed parents in particular.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompared with nonparents, employed parents are twice as likely to strongly agree that they:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eare worn out at the end of the day,\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eused to find their work more interesting, and\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003esometimes think their work is insignificant.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to the pandemic-related challenges that people around the world are facing\u0026mdash;including illness, financial worry, and isolation from friends and family\u0026mdash;employed parents in the United States have had distinct challenges stemming from the COVID-19 crisis. As our survey of employed parents indicates, the compound pressure of working while parenting, including remote schooling and working, has left many citing feelings of apathy and fatigue, and as if they are failing to live up to their own expectations across their multiple social roles. These may include expectations related to not only being a parent, but as a spouse, friend, family member, or caregiver.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are also indications that parents are not finding the help they need from their employers. For example, in our survey, parents reporting symptoms of burnout are 90 percent more likely to report that they believe senior management at their workplace considers productivity to be more important than mental health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePopulations of color have faced disproportionate job losses and are experiencing a death toll twice that of the White population from COVID-19.[[footnote 4]] Less than a third of employed parents of color said, \u0026ldquo;I enjoy my work. I have no symptoms of burnout,\u0026rdquo; compared with almost half of White parents who said the same.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBeyond facing more health-specific concerns and health-related trauma in their communities, employed parents of color have also had more challenges around childcare. For example, families of color have been more likely than White families to experience pandemic-related childcare closures.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile our survey analysis focused on US respondents, parents around the globe are experiencing fatigue and stress.[[footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up learnmore]]\n[[pullquote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eMany employers are recognizing these challenges and are beginning to develop and implement strategies to support their employees in new and different ways. The research and perspectives presented here are offered to support employers as they define and refine their approaches. In the charts below, we highlight some of the meaningful findings from the research and identify actions that employers could consider.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCauses of burnout for employed parents stem from both the home and the workplace\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eOf the six main causes of burnout\u0026mdash;an unsustainable workload, a general perceived lack of control, insufficient rewards for effort, the lack of a supportive community, absence of fairness, and mismatched values and skills\u0026mdash;many are challenges that employed parents may be more likely to face, particularly in a pandemic.[[footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[pullquote 2]]\n[[pullquote 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eEmployed parents report a range of stressors that have deteriorated their mental health. The level of household responsibilities is a particular problem. In our survey, parents experiencing symptoms of burnout are more often responsible for all household duties, compared with parents not experiencing symptoms of burnout (57 percent versus 41 percent).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[pullquote 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn fact, the majority of parents responsible for all household duties report symptoms of burnout. These responsibilities, for example, including caring for \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/supporting-unpaid-caregivers-in-crisis-a-talk-with-alexandra-drane\"\u003e older adult family members\u003c/a\u003e in addition to children, most often fall to women, who have also been more likely to cut back on paid work during the COVID-19 pandemic in order to provide childcare.[[footnote 8]] For these women specifically, reduced paid time at work could also serve to further exacerbate the symptoms of burnout they are experiencing, if their responsibilities at work do not also decrease.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[pullquote 5]]\n[[story 1]]\n[[pullquote 6]]\n[[story 2]]\n[[pullquote 7]]\n[[disruptor1up readnext]]\n\u003ch2\u003eEmployers can consider taking a preventative approach toward burnout\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMeasures that support flexibility and resiliency can help ensure that all employees are engaged in their mental wellness.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFlexible working policies can be a critical tool for both parent and nonparent employees. Parents with access to flexible working policies are substantially less likely to show symptoms of burnout. Conversely, parents reporting symptoms of burnout who are unaware of flexible policies at work are more likely to request similar policies and to believe that these options would benefit them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt is important for employers to realize that flexible working policies can come in many forms, going beyond remote-work options and including options such as reducing an individual\u0026rsquo;s work responsibilities and offering part-time work.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[pullquote 8]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe following are the top policies and benefits that parents were most likely to request to support their mental health:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eflexible work schedule\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eremote-work options (independent of the COVID-19 pandemic)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003efamily-support services (eg, childcare or dependent-care stipends, backup care)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eskill-building programs (eg, sleep improvement, stress-management programs)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003efamily or medical leave for mental-health conditions\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[pullquote 9]]\n\u003ch2\u003eEmployers can consider certain initiatives to better support employed parents experiencing burnout\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEmployers \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/national-surveys-reveal-disconnect-between-employees-and-employers-around-mental-health-need\"\u003etaking steps\u003c/a\u003e to address their employees\u0026rsquo; mental health\u0026mdash;including helping them to feel included and valued\u0026mdash;can begin this journey by actively listening to their employees to better understand the challenges they face and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/future-proof-solving-the-adaptability-paradox-for-the-long-term\"\u003eby acting on what they hear\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor employers, actively supporting parents\u0026rsquo; mental health can lead to many forms of positive impact. By \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/overcoming-pandemic-fatigue-how-to-reenergize-organizations-for-the-long-run\"\u003etaking steps to prevent burnout and stress\u003c/a\u003e, an employer can help enable both employees and their families to thrive. Additionally, by acting to prevent and reduce burnout among employed parents, employers are not only supporting a population that, in turn, is more likely to remain in the workforce down the line and to endorse the organization to others, but also \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/women-in-the-workplace-archive\"\u003ecreating a more supportive organization overall\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubsequent steps may include the following.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMake parents feel heard\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eManagers can lead with compassion, working with their teams on promoting well-being, addressing stress, exhaustion, and burnout, and encouraging open discussion on topics of mental health by sharing their own stories.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eInvolve parents in conversations around how they would most appreciate employer support, particularly in times of uncertainty (for example, on topics such as return to in-person working and organizational changes). Consider affinity groups to help foster connectivity.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eRefine organizational support plans for parents by addressing uncovered pain points and needs.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBuild a work culture that supports mental health\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eEstablish flexibility around remote working (for example, flexibility to work from home as needed, or flexible hours) and communicate expectations early. Establish formal boundaries to help prevent employees from feeling that they need to be \u0026ldquo;always on\u0026rdquo; (for example, policies that make it clear that employees are not expected to respond to nonurgent requests outside of traditional working hours). Allow managers to work with direct reports in defining their responsibilities.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAllow employees to adjust their workload as needed to tend to caregiving responsibilities, with ability to transition between full and part time as is feasible. When possible, allow employees to transition to more time-flexible roles (for example, from an inbound to an outbound call center, or from a direct customer-facing role to one involving document review).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eStructure performance reviews to reemphasize that employees are evaluated on results over simply where or what hours they work. Ensure in day-to-day and formal communications that leaders are not inadvertently signaling that long hours and face time are measures of performance.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eProvide critical resources aligned with employees\u0026rsquo; priorities\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOffer clear guidance on navigating the healthcare landscape for employed parents to support their or their children\u0026rsquo;s mental-health needs (for example, by creating a central internal landing page highlighting in-network child therapists).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eConsider providing more options for childcare support (for example, subsidized, on-site, or back-up childcare), nursing services, and other home- and family-focused benefits, showing value and support of employees as people juggling multiple roles.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eEnsure that benefits and other programs supporting mental health (for example, digital wellness apps) include access for close family members, such as employees\u0026rsquo; children.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-12-17T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBased on McKinsey survey data of employees in the United States. The survey was open for responses between July 7 and July 14, 2021; n = 3,007. Of those surveyed, 862 were employed parents. We use the term \u0026ldquo;employed parents\u0026rdquo; to refer to individuals who work outside the home and who are parents/caregivers of children aged 18 and younger who live at home.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBurnout is defined by the World Health Organization, in its 11th revision of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11), as a syndrome resulting from chronic workplace stress that has not been successfully managed. Burnout is characterized by three dimensions: (1) feelings of energy depletion or exhaustion, (2) increased mental distance from one\u0026rsquo;s job or feelings of negativism or cynicism related to one\u0026rsquo;s job, and (3) reduced professional efficacy.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eWhen managed well, experiencing stress can serve a purpose\u0026mdash;it can help us to solve problems and to learn and grow. However, when left unmanaged, stress can lead to burnout.
